docs.lead_paragraph: THE natural world is a study in proportions: giraffes with outrageously long necks, Tyrannosaurus rex with its tiny arms, and supermodels with legs that go on and on. But despite all the fun-house-mirror changes wrought by evolution, a lot of imaginable creatures have never existed. Pondering the gaps in the endless spectrum of possibilities, some biologists have wondered whether it might be strictures of the developmental programs that build organisms -- the rules that guide their growth from single cell to intricate adult -- that could make building some kinds of creatures impossible.

headline.main: In Growth of Body Parts, Darwinian Competition

docs.abstract: Evolutionary biologists ponder questions of relationships among various body parts in organisms, and question of whether body parts compete for resources, limiting each other's growth and final size, apparently preventing features from evolving to all imaginable proportions; some biologists wonder whether it might be strictures of the developmental programs that build organisms--the rules that guide their growth from single cell to intricate adult--that could make building some kinds of creatures impossible; new study suggests that such architectural limitations may well be widespread; study also suggests that these constraints may be caused by entirely unexpected developmental phenomenon: competition among growing body parts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Let's see -- one adoption agency received $12,500; a second, $6,000; the adoptive parents got the child of their dreams. And Gina Bruystens, struggling to pay her bills, received $400 a month, had some medical bills paid during her pregnancy and got a box of new maternity clothes. Oh, I almost forgot. Her son got a stuffed animal.
docs.abstract: Gloria DiPietro Cooper letter disputes Lisa Belkin's April 5 article on motherhood, which focused on increasing number of birth mothers giving up children for adoption and described case of Gina Bruystens (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was gratifying to see Lisa Belkin's article about a birth mother in your special issue (''Now Accepting Applications for My Baby''). Gina Bruystens is portrayed as going through her pregnancy and adoptive placement in a straightforward and determined manner. For many birth mothers, however, this is an emotional, sometimes mournful, time.
docs.abstract: Letter from Spence-Chapin Services director Judy Greene comments on Lisa Belkin's April 5 article on motherhood, which focused on increasing number of birth mothers giving up children for adoption; says even though Gina Bruystens went through pregnancy and adoptive placement in straightforward and determined manner, for many birth mothers, it is emotional and sometimes mournful time (S)

keywords.value: SPENCE-CHAPIN SERVICES TO FAMILIES AND CHILDREN

docs.lead_paragraph: THE 42-year-old from Suffolk County had a strong family history of breast cancer. Her mother, a sister and two aunts had died of the disease. When she learned that she could be genetically tested to find out whether she had the BRCA-1 gene, which predisposes carriers to breast cancer, the woman, who insisted on anonymity, went to University Hospital at Stony Brook.

headline.main: Genetic Tests Gaining for Adult-Onset Ills

docs.abstract: Article on recent advances in predictive gene testing which are allowing people to learn if they are at greater risk of getting certain diseases; focuses on work at five Long Island hospitals (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Roger Spurback, a lifelong Republican in this city of Democrats, used to heap praise on Gov. George E. Pataki and his fiscal policies. But his feelings changed when Mr. Pataki cut $20,000 from the state budget for a neighborhood crime prevention program that Mr. Spurback supervises from his home here. The program is among hundreds that suffered when Mr. Pataki vetoed more than $1.5 billion in state spending last week, saying legislators had pledged far too many tax dollars to programs great and small. While the vetoes will affect the entire state, people like Mr. Spurback say their impact will be harshest in depressed upstate cities like Niagara Falls, where many community programs rely almost entirely on state aid. Even politically conservative residents like Mr. Spurback are livid, saying the vetoes will lead many to vote against Mr. Pataki this fall.

headline.main: In Niagara Falls, Pataki's Vetoes Rouse Anger as Economy Slumps

docs.abstract: Niagara Falls, NY, is among several depressed upstate communities that are to be hard hit by Gov George Pataki's veto of more than $1.5 billion in state spending last week; many community programs like those of Niagara Falls rely almost entirely on state aid; even politically conservative residents are angry and say vetoes will lead many to vote against Pataki this fall; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Roger Spurback, a lifelong Republican in this city of Democrats, used to heap praise on Gov. George E. Pataki and his fiscal policies. But his feelings changed when Mr. Pataki cut $20,000 from the state budget for a neighborhood crime prevention...

docs.lead_paragraph: IN Westchester, as in other parts of the state last week, bitter disappointment followed Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of $1.6 billion in proposed state spending. High hopes were dashed for new library services, improved school buildings, richer arts programs and other items included in the original fiscal proposal. And many state legislators who had been exulting about this year's almost on-time budget -- one that was hammered out in the open rather than behind closed doors -- were forced to deliver bad news to constituents in an election year. ''Money for Westchester Community College and SUNY Purchase, gone! Money for the Arts Council, gone!'' exclaimed an indignant State Assemblyman, Richard L. Brodsky of Greenburgh, reeling off a list of Mr. Pataki's cuts. ''The vetoes are especially bad for Westchester.''

headline.main: Disappointment Follows Vetoes Of State Spending

docs.abstract: Article on adverse impact on Westchester County public works projects as result of Gov George Pataki's veto of $1.6 billion in proposed state spending; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the back of every parent's mind, crowded in with worries about the job, the bills, the waistline and grandma, is a certain fear about the children -- that we haven't prepared them well enough, that their world won't be good enough, that we can't do anything about it. No wonder so many parents are glum. Fortunately, someone decided to ask the children how they are. A New York Times/CBS News Poll of about 1,000 children age 13 to 17 divulged its results this week. Some of the news, of course, is dismaying. Almost 60 percent of the teen-agers said they had cheated on some exam. Half said they knew someone who had attempted suicide. Almost 20 percent knew someone who had the AIDS virus or had died of it. More thought that drugs were a big problem in their schools than in 1994. Fewer were happy with the way they looked than kids were four years ago. But most of them won't be reading about it in this editorial, because about three-quarters don't read a newspaper most days of the week.
docs.abstract: Editorial on life styles and attitudes of American teen-agers, as seen through New York Times/CBS Poll; reports that staggering two-thirds say television is their most constant companiion, but most also say they believe in God and usually have dinner with their families; says responses suggest that world is better place than we adults suspect, that this generation's lives will be happier than we can know, and that we have done more for them than we think

docs.lead_paragraph: In a trend that some credit mostly to abstinence education and others to better use of contraception, teen-age birth rates nationwide declined substantially from 1991 to 1996. According to the National Center for Health Statistics, the sharpest declines were among black teen-agers, until recently the group with the highest level of births.

headline.main: Birth Rates for Teen-Agers Declined Sharply in the 90's

docs.abstract: US National Center for Health Statistics reports that teen-age birth rates nationwide declined substantially from 1991 to 1996, in trend that some credit mostly to abstinence education and others to better use of contraception; sharpest declines are among black teen-agers, until recently the group with highest level of births; while black teen-agers still have babies at almost twice the rate of whites, their birth rate declined 21 percent from 1991 to 1996, and is now at lowest level ever reported; there were 91.7 births for every 1,000 black teen-age women ages 15 to 19 in 1996, while whites had 48.4 per 1,000, and Hispanic teen-agers had 101.6; graphs; map (M)
